objectives: Understand that nouns are words that name people, places, animals, or things.
Learn to identify different kinds of nouns like common, proper, concrete, and abstract nouns.
Practice using singular and plural nouns correctly in simple sentences.

sections.text: A noun is a word that names a person, a place, an animal, or a thing. Everything around us has a name, and these names are nouns. Think of all the things you see in your village, at home, or at school â€“ almost everything has a name, and that name is a noun.

examples.label: Person
examples.value: Teacher, farmer, mother, student, Ram, doctor, friend

examples.label: Place
examples.value: Village, school, field, market, home, well, city, river

examples.label: Animal
examples.value: Cow, goat, dog, bird, fish, lion, cat

examples.label: Thing
examples.value: Book, pen, chair, water, tree, soil, tractor, mobile

sections.text: Common nouns are general names for people, places, animals, or things. They do not name any one special or particular thing. They are not capitalized unless they start a sentence.

examples.label: Person
examples.value: boy, girl, man, woman, teacher, doctor, friend, sister

examples.label: Place
examples.value: village, city, river, mountain, school, shop, farm, hospital

examples.label: Animal
examples.value: dog, cat, cow, bird, monkey, snake, tiger, horse

examples.label: Thing
examples.value: table, chair, pen, book, flower, crop, phone, computer

usage_examples: I saw a **river** flowing near the **mountain**.
I saw a beautiful **flower** in the **garden**.

sections.text: Proper nouns are special names for particular people, places, animals, or things. They always begin with a capital letter, no matter where they are in a sentence. Think of names of people, specific villages, festivals, or months.

examples.label: Specific Person
examples.value: Ram, Sita, Rahul, Meena, Uncle Sharma, Mrs. Devi

examples.label: Specific Place
examples.value: Delhi, Mumbai, India, Maharashtra, Ganga River, Taj Mahal, Shantipur

examples.label: Specific Animal (Name)
examples.value: Buddy (a dog's name), Shera (a lion's name), Moti (a cow's name)

examples.label: Specific Thing/Event/Time
examples.value: Diwali, Holi, January, Monday, English (language), The Ramayana (book)

usage_examples: My friend **Rahul** and I study at **Adarsh Public School**.
My favorite day of the week is **Sunday**.
We are going to **Mumbai** for our holidays.

subtopics.title: 2.3. Concrete Nouns: Things We Can See and Touch

sections.text: Concrete nouns are names of things you can see, touch, hear, smell, or taste. They are real, physical things. Most common nouns are also concrete nouns.

examples.label: See
examples.value: Tree, road, house, cloud, sun, moon, star

examples.label: Touch
examples.value: Stone, water, soil, book, pen, hand, cloth, table

examples.label: Hear
examples.value: Bell, music, rain, bird (the sound), thunder, horn

examples.label: Smell
examples.value: Flower, food, smoke, perfume, soil (after rain)

examples.label: Taste
examples.value: Mango, rice, salt, sugar, lemon, water

usage_examples: I can hear the **bell** ringing for school.
The **soil** in the **field** is very fertile.
I can smell the **smoke** from the fire.
The **rain** is falling on the tin roof.
My **mother** is cooking **food** in the kitchen.
I am writing with a **pen** in my **notebook**.
I can feel the **wind** on my **face**.

sections.text: Abstract nouns are names of ideas, feelings, qualities, or conditions that you cannot see, touch, hear, smell, or taste. They are things that exist in our minds or as concepts.

examples.label: Feeling
examples.value: Happiness, sadness, anger, love, fear, joy, excitement

examples.label: Idea
examples.value: Freedom, knowledge, truth, peace, justice, idea, dream

examples.label: Quality
examples.value: Kindness, bravery, honesty, beauty, courage, patience, wisdom

examples.label: Condition
examples.value: Poverty, sickness, childhood, friendship, health, wealth

usage_examples: We all wish for **peace** in our village.
She felt great **happiness** on her birthday.
It is important to always tell the **truth**.
The soldier was awarded for his **bravery**.
You need a lot of **patience** for this work.
The old man is known for his **wisdom**.
She has a great **love** for animals.

sections.text: Collective nouns are words that name a group or collection of people, animals, or things as a single unit.

examples.label: Group of People
examples.value: family, team, army, crowd, class, audience

examples.label: Group of Animals
examples.value: herd (of cows), flock (of sheep/birds), swarm (of bees), pack (of wolves)

examples.label: Group of Things
examples.value: bunch (of keys/grapes), fleet (of ships), forest (of trees), library (of books)

usage_examples: Our **family** lives in a small house.
A **herd** of cows is grazing in the field.
I saw a **flock** of birds flying south.
She gave me a **bunch** of grapes.
A large **crowd** gathered at the market.
A **swarm** of bees flew out of the hive.
Our school has a big **library** of books.

subtopics.title: 2.6. Compound Nouns: Two Words Make One Noun

sections.text: Compound nouns are made up of two or more words combined to create a single noun. They can be written as one word, as two separate words, or with a hyphen.

examples.label: One Word (Closed)
examples.value: classroom, football, sunlight, homework, notebook, bedroom

examples.label: Two Words (Open)
examples.value: village well, post office, bus stop, water tank, living room, high school

examples.label: Hyphenated
examples.value: mother-in-law, sister-in-law, self-control, ten-year-old

usage_examples: The **post office** is near the school.
The **water tank** for our village is huge.

sections.text: A singular noun names only one person, place, animal, or thing.

examples.label: One Person
examples.value: girl, boy, teacher, man, woman, child

examples.label: One Place
examples.value: village, farm, school, house, shop, temple

examples.label: One Animal
examples.value: cow, goat, dog, bird, horse, lion

examples.label: One Thing
examples.value: book, pen, tree, flower, table, bus

usage_examples: There is a big **tree** near our house.
There is a **bus** at the bus stop.

sections.text: A plural noun names more than one person, place, animal, or thing. Most nouns become plural by adding '-s' at the end. But some nouns have special rules.

examples.label: Adding '-s'
examples.value: cow -> cows, book -> books, village -> villages, flower -> flowers

examples.label: Adding '-es' (for s, x, z, sh, ch)
examples.value: bus -> buses, box -> boxes, bench -> benches, bush -> bushes

examples.label: Changing 'y' to 'ies' (if 'y' comes after consonant)
examples.value: story -> stories, family -> families, city -> cities, baby -> babies

examples.label: Changing 'f'/'fe' to 'ves'
examples.value: leaf -> leaves, knife -> knives, wife -> wives, life -> lives

examples.label: Irregular Plurals (No rule)
examples.value: man -> men, child -> children, mouse -> mice, foot -> feet, tooth -> teeth

usage_examples: We have many **cows** on our farm.
There are three **books** on the table.
The **children** are playing in the field.
The **buses** arrive early at the station.
Our **families** live together in the village.
The **leaves** on the trees are turning yellow.
The **stories** my grandmother tells are interesting.
The **men** and **women** work together on the farm.
There are many **benches** in the park.
I need to buy new **knives** for the kitchen.

subtopics.title: 4.1. Making Nouns Show Who Owns Something

sections.text: Possessive nouns show that something belongs to a person, animal, or thing. We usually use an apostrophe (') and an 's' to show this ownership.
To show ownership for a singular noun, add an apostrophe (') and an 's' at the end of the noun.

examples.label: Example 1
examples.value: The book of the boy -> the **boy's** book

examples.label: Example 2
examples.value: The tail of the cow -> the **cow's** tail

examples.label: Example 3
examples.value: The house of Ram -> **Ram's** house

sections.text: For plural nouns that already end in 's', just add an apostrophe (') after the 's'. For plural nouns that do not end in 's' (irregular plurals), add an apostrophe and an 's'.

examples.label: Plural ending in 's'
examples.value: The books of the boys -> the **boys'** books

examples.label: Plural ending in 's'
examples.value: The work of the farmers -> the **farmers'** work

examples.label: Plural not ending in 's'
examples.value: The toys of the children -> the **children's** toys

examples.label: Plural not ending in 's'
examples.value: The meeting of the men -> the **men's** meeting

usage_examples: We need to clean the **cows'** shed.
My **parents'** house is in the village.
The **teachers'** room is on the first floor.
You can hear the **birds'** songs in the morning.
The **horses'** stables are behind the house.

sections.text: Nouns are very important in sentences. They can act as the subject (who or what is doing the action) or the object (who or what is receiving the action).

examples.label: Subject
examples.value: The **farmer** works hard. (**Farmer** is the one working.)

examples.label: Subject
examples.value: **Rain** helps the crops grow. (**Rain** is doing the action of helping.)

examples.label: Object
examples.value: I read a **book**. (**Book** is what I read.)

examples.label: Object
examples.value: She gave **water** to the plant. (**Water** is what she gave.)

examples.label: Subject and Object
examples.value: The **teacher** (S) explains the **lesson** (O).

usage_examples: The **well** (S) provides clean **water** (O) for the village.
